The mentioned article is only talking about nsp and not snyk.
I thought of maybe adding this article as well -
https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2016/01/eliminating-known-security-vulnerabilities-with-snyk/
And maybe this quote -

Running untrusted code inside your system poses a broad security risk. Tackling it isn’t simple, but a good place to start is by addressing known vulnerabilities. These are publicly disclosed security bugs, typically found and logged by users, or intentionally found and reported by security researchers. Being public makes these issues the easiest ones for attackers to find and exploit, and so very important to address.


Right now, roughly 14% of the top npm packages carry known vulnerabilities. The stats are far worse for full applications: over 80% of Snyk users find vulnerabilities when testing their applications.

The only issue with it it's seem like a promotional peace for snyk and was written by one of their co-founders

This piece of advice isn't exactly node specific, but since Node is often deployed in a microservice environment, I think it's absolutely crucial to expose system health to all dependent systems. Even if you're not in a microservice environment, being able to view system health at a glance can be a tremendous relief.
I work in a company with a fleet of 100+ services across thousands of instances. We have developed a schema that all our services have to adhere to. Part of it is to expose a healthcheck endpoint that tells you the overall health of the system, as well as information about each individual check - including dependencies. This allows us to create a graph of connected services so that if there's an outage in one system, we can see which other systems will be affected by it. It can also help us discover bottlenecks where one system may affect many others, in which case we should strive to provide fallback behaviors that allow us to at least partially function.
For the record, I'm the developer of express-physical, which I linked to in the "read more" section. We use that library across all of our node services, and it has worked well for us so far.

Hello again guys!
In this PR, I'm translating the Latest Best Practices and News, and some other details that I was missing! 😃

Translated Section 6 Read More files
And fixed a typo

⛏ What work is being done here?
Only "One Paragraph Explainer" from inner sections are being translated in this PR. For further discussion and planning please take a look at the official spanish translation issue: #95.
📝 Task list

 Translate 51 "one paragraph explainers" to a private Excel (by Seth)
 Carefully review and polish translations (by desko27)
 Actually add them to the PR (by desko27)

✅ Sections 1-5 → Translations from 1 to 34 - 100%

 1) Structure your solution by components
 2) Layer your app, keep Express within its boundaries
 3) Wrap common utilities as npm packages
 4) Separate Express 'app' and 'server'
 5) Use environment aware, secure and hierarchical config
 6) Use Async-Await or promises for async error handling
 7) Use only the built-in Error object
 8) Distinguish operational vs programmer errors
 9) Handle errors centrally. Not within middlewares
 10) Document API errors using Swagger
 11) Exit the process gracefully when a stranger comes to town
 12) Use a mature logger to increase errors visibility
 13) Test error flows using your favorite test framework
 14) Discover errors and downtime using APM products
 15) Catch unhandled promise rejections
 16) Fail fast, validate arguments using a dedicated library
 17) Carefully choose your CI platform
 18) Monitoring!
 20) Make your app transparent using smart logs
 21) Delegate anything possible (e.g. static content, gzip) to a reverse proxy
 22) Lock dependencies
 23) Guard and restart your process upon failure (using the right tool)
 24) Utilize all CPU cores
 25) Create a maintenance endpoint
 26) Sure user experience with APM products
 27) Make your code production-ready
 28) Measure and guard the memory usage
 29) Get your frontend assets out of Node
 30) Be stateless, kill your Servers almost every day
 31) Use tools that automatically detect vulnerable dependencies
 32) Assign ‘TransactionId’ to each log statement
 33) Set NODE_ENV = production
 34) Use an LTS release of Node.js in production

🔄 Section 6 → Translations from 35 to 51 - 0%

 35) Embrace linter security rules
 36) Limit concurrent requests using a balancer or a middleware
 37) Common Node.js security best practices
 38) Using HTTPS to encrypt the client-server connection
 39) Using security-related headers to secure your application against common attacks
 40) Constantly and automatically inspect for vulnerable dependencies
 41) Avoid using the Node.js Crypto library for passwords, use Bcrypt
 42) Escape Output
 43) Validate the incoming JSON schemas
 44) Support blacklisting JWT tokens
 45) Run Node.js as Non-Root User
 46) Limit payload size using a reverse-proxy or a middleware
 47) Avoid JS eval statements
 48) Prevent malicious RegEx from overloading your single thread execution
 49) Avoid module loading using a variable
 50) Hide error details from client
 51) Modify the default session middleware settings

I hope I integrated all feedback from this issue, while leaving the core message intact: People should be aware how statements are separated or linked together, and that there are cases where ASI and/or semicolon do not help, if statement termination is not understood. This also leaves room for the reader to prefer semicolons or not.

Must have newlines before the HTML comments as Docusaurus will fail to build without it.
I assume that when they are right after the HTML the parsing done by Docusaurus thinks these comments are part of the HTML which will try to convert it into a React component which would fail the build as HTML comments in React are unsupported (instead of <!-- some comment --> you need to do {/* comment */})

There were some links that were inside of HTML comments as I assume because they weren't exist
Replace those dead translation links with the original ones.
Apparently, even links in comments are been checked before run/build in Docusaurus

I was going through to fix my profile image in the README.md, and realized there wasn't any consistency to the avatar icons and all look a little tacky if someone is using github's dark theme since there's no transparency around the circle. So I created an svg template with a clip path that you can load up in most tools that support svg and export with transparency.
I also added SVGs for the icons used in committee section, since those also look kind of funky in in other themes.
While messing with things I discovered that adding min-width to the contributor template somehow still affects the profile images even though it gets sanitized away, so I added that so that there's a lot less shifting of the contributors table.
I probably need to revert it, but I was curious if there's any reason the README's for the other languages aren't included in the automated contributors updates?
